significantEvents.title: Whiskey Rebellion
significantEvents.description: A domestic uprising against the federal excise tax on whiskey.

significantEvents.title: Proclamation of Neutrality
significantEvents.description: Declared the U.S. neutral in the conflict between France and Great Britain.

presidents.name: John Adams
presidents.burialLocation: United First Parish Church, Quincy, Massachusetts

significantEvents.title: Alien and Sedition Acts
significantEvents.description: Legislation that restricted immigration and limited speech critical of the government.

significantEvents.title: Quasi-War with France
significantEvents.description: An undeclared naval war between the U.S. and France.

significantEvents.title: Louisiana Purchase
significantEvents.description: Doubled the size of the U.S. by purchasing territory from France.

significantEvents.title: Embargo Act
significantEvents.description: Prohibited American ships from trading in foreign ports.

significantEvents.title: War of 1812
significantEvents.description: Conflict between the U.S. and Great Britain over trade and territorial disputes.

significantEvents.title: Monroe Doctrine
significantEvents.description: U.S. foreign policy opposing European colonialism in the Americas.

significantEvents.title: Missouri Compromise
significantEvents.description: Legislation that regulated slavery in western territories.

presidents.name: John Quincy Adams
presidents.burialLocation: United First Parish Church, Quincy, Massachusetts

significantEvents.title: Erie Canal Completion
significantEvents.description: The Erie Canal was completed, connecting the Great Lakes to the Atlantic Ocean.

significantEvents.title: Corrupt Bargain Controversy
significantEvents.description: Accusations of a political deal between Adams and Henry Clay in the contested election of 1824.

presidents.name: Andrew Jackson
presidents.placeOfBirth: Waxhaws Region, North Carolina/South Carolina Border

significantEvents.title: Indian Removal Act
significantEvents.description: Authorized the forced relocation of Native American tribes to lands west of the Mississippi.

significantEvents.title: Nullification Crisis
significantEvents.description: A confrontation with South Carolina over the state's attempt to nullify federal tariffs.

significantEvents.title: Panic of 1837
significantEvents.description: A financial crisis that led to a severe economic depression.

significantEvents.title: Amistad Case
significantEvents.description: A court case involving enslaved Africans who revolted aboard the ship Amistad.

presidents.name: William Henry Harrison
presidents.burialLocation: Harrison Tomb State Memorial, North Bend, Ohio

terms.reasonForIncompletion: Died of pneumonia after 31 days in office

significantEvents.title: Annexation of Texas
significantEvents.description: Signed a resolution to annex Texas into the United States.

significantEvents.title: Mexican-American War
significantEvents.description: Conflict between the U.S. and Mexico, resulting in the acquisition of territories in the southwest.

significantEvents.title: Oregon Treaty
significantEvents.description: Established the U.S.-Canada border along the 49th parallel in the Pacific Northwest.

presidents.name: Zachary Taylor
presidents.burialLocation: Zachary Taylor National Cemetery, Louisville, Kentucky

terms.reasonForIncompletion: Died of illness while in office

significantEvents.title: Debate over the Compromise of 1850
significantEvents.description: A contentious series of bills intended to resolve disputes over slavery in new territories.

presidents.name: Millard Fillmore
presidents.burialLocation: Forest Lawn Cemetery, Buffalo, New York

significantEvents.title: Compromise of 1850
significantEvents.description: A series of bills aiming to ease tensions between free and slave states.

significantEvents.title: Fugitive Slave Act
significantEvents.description: Part of the Compromise of 1850, this law required the return of escaped slaves to their owners.

presidents.name: Franklin Pierce
presidents.burialLocation: Old North Cemetery, Concord, New Hampshire

significantEvents.title: Kansas-Nebraska Act
significantEvents.description: Legislation that allowed territories to decide on slavery, leading to violent conflicts.

significantEvents.title: Gadsden Purchase
significantEvents.description: Acquired land from Mexico to facilitate a southern transcontinental railroad.

significantEvents.title: Dred Scott Decision
significantEvents.description: Supreme Court ruling that African Americans could not be citizens and Congress had no power to regulate slavery in territories.

significantEvents.title: John Brown's Raid on Harpers Ferry
significantEvents.description: An abolitionist attempt to incite a slave rebellion.

significantEvents.title: Emancipation Proclamation
significantEvents.description: Declared all slaves in Confederate states to be free.

significantEvents.title: Gettysburg Address
significantEvents.description: A famous speech delivered at the dedication of the Gettysburg National Cemetery.

presidents.name: Andrew Johnson
presidents.burialLocation: Andrew Johnson National Cemetery, Greeneville, Tennessee

significantEvents.title: Reconstruction Era
significantEvents.description: Oversaw the reintegration of Southern states into the Union after the Civil War.

significantEvents.title: Impeachment Trial
significantEvents.description: The first U.S. president to be impeached, but acquitted by one vote in the Senate.

presidents.name: Ulysses S. Grant
presidents.burialLocation: Grant's Tomb, New York City, New York

significantEvents.title: 15th Amendment Ratification
significantEvents.description: Guaranteed voting rights regardless of race or previous servitude.

significantEvents.title: Credit Mobilier Scandal
significantEvents.description: A corruption scandal involving railroad construction and government officials.

significantEvents.title: Compromise of 1877
significantEvents.description: An informal deal that ended Reconstruction and resolved the disputed 1876 election.

significantEvents.title: Great Railroad Strike of 1877
significantEvents.description: A nationwide labor strike against wage cuts in the railroad industry.

significantEvents.title: Assassination
significantEvents.description: Shot by Charles J. Guiteau and succumbed to his injuries two months later.

presidents.name: Chester A. Arthur
presidents.burialLocation: Albany Rural Cemetery, Menands, New York

significantEvents.title: Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act
significantEvents.description: Established a merit-based system for federal employment.

significantEvents.title: Chinese Exclusion Act
significantEvents.description: Prohibited immigration of Chinese laborers to the United States.

significantEvents.title: Presidential Succession Act
significantEvents.description: Defined the line of succession to the presidency.

significantEvents.title: Statue of Liberty Dedication
significantEvents.description: The Statue of Liberty was dedicated in New York Harbor.

significantEvents.title: Sherman Antitrust Act
significantEvents.description: First federal act to prohibit monopolistic business practices.

significantEvents.title: Electricity in the White House
significantEvents.description: The White House was wired for electricity during his term.

significantEvents.title: Panic of 1893
significantEvents.description: A financial crisis that led to a severe economic depression.

significantEvents.title: Pullman Strike
significantEvents.description: A nationwide railroad strike that affected the economy and led to federal intervention.

significantEvents.title: Spanish-American War
significantEvents.description: Conflict between the U.S. and Spain, resulting in U.S. control of Guam, Puerto Rico, and the Philippines.

significantEvents.title: Annexation of Hawaii
significantEvents.description: Hawaii was annexed as a U.S. territory.

presidents.name: Theodore Roosevelt
presidents.burialLocation: Youngs Memorial Cemetery, Oyster Bay, New York

significantEvents.title: Panama Canal Construction Begins
significantEvents.description: Oversaw the start of the Panama Canal project, connecting the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans.

significantEvents.title: Roosevelt Corollary
significantEvents.description: Asserted U.S. authority in Latin America as an extension of the Monroe Doctrine.

significantEvents.title: Antitrust Policy
significantEvents.description: Broke up major monopolies, including Standard Oil.

significantEvents.title: Income Tax Amendment
significantEvents.description: The 16th Amendment, allowing Congress to levy an income tax, was ratified.

significantEvents.title: World War I
significantEvents.description: Entered the U.S. into World War I to support Allied forces.

significantEvents.title: League of Nations
significantEvents.description: Championed the creation of the League of Nations as part of the Treaty of Versailles.

significantEvents.title: Teapot Dome Scandal
significantEvents.description: A bribery scandal involving federal oil reserves.

significantEvents.title: Budget and Accounting Act
significantEvents.description: Established the Bureau of the Budget and required annual budget submissions to Congress.

significantEvents.title: Revenue Act of 1924
significantEvents.description: Reduced income tax rates and established the U.S. Board of Tax Appeals.

significantEvents.title: Immigration Act of 1924
significantEvents.description: Restricted immigration by establishing national origin quotas.

presidents.name: Herbert Hoover
presidents.burialLocation: Herbert Hoover Presidential Library and Museum, West Branch, Iowa

significantEvents.title: Stock Market Crash of 1929
significantEvents.description: Marked the beginning of the Great Depression.

significantEvents.title: Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act
significantEvents.description: Raised tariffs on imported goods, worsening global economic conditions.

presidents.name: Franklin D. Roosevelt
presidents.burialLocation: Springwood Estate, Hyde Park, New York

significantEvents.title: New Deal
significantEvents.description: A series of programs and reforms to combat the Great Depression.

significantEvents.title: World War II
significantEvents.description: Led the U.S. during most of World War II as part of the Allied Powers.

presidents.name: Harry S. Truman
presidents.burialLocation: Truman Presidential Library and Museum, Independence, Missouri

significantEvents.title: Atomic Bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki
significantEvents.description: Ordered the use of atomic bombs to end World War II.

significantEvents.title: Marshall Plan
significantEvents.description: Economic aid to rebuild European countries after World War II.

presidents.name: Dwight D. Eisenhower
presidents.burialLocation: Eisenhower Presidential Library, Museum and Boyhood Home, Abilene, Kansas

significantEvents.title: Interstate Highway System
significantEvents.description: Signed the Federal-Aid Highway Act, creating the modern highway system.

significantEvents.title: Civil Rights Act of 1957
significantEvents.description: First civil rights legislation since Reconstruction, focusing on voting rights.

significantEvents.title: Cuban Missile Crisis
significantEvents.description: A 13-day confrontation with the Soviet Union over missiles in Cuba.

significantEvents.title: Space Race
significantEvents.description: Declared the goal of landing a man on the Moon before the decade's end.

significantEvents.title: Civil Rights Act of 1964
significantEvents.description: Prohibited discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, or national origin.

significantEvents.title: Great Society
significantEvents.description: A series of domestic programs aimed at eliminating poverty and racial injustice.

presidents.name: Richard Nixon
presidents.burialLocation: Richard Nixon Presidential Library and Museum, Yorba Linda, California

significantEvents.title: Watergate Scandal
significantEvents.description: A political scandal that led to Nixon's resignation.

significantEvents.title: Apollo 11 Moon Landing
significantEvents.description: The first human Moon landing during Nixon's presidency.

presidents.name: Gerald Ford
presidents.burialLocation: Gerald R. Ford Presidential Museum, Grand Rapids, Michigan

significantEvents.title: Pardon of Richard Nixon
significantEvents.description: Ford granted a full pardon to Nixon for any crimes he might have committed as president.

significantEvents.title: Fall of Saigon
significantEvents.description: Marked the end of the Vietnam War.

significantEvents.title: Camp David Accords
significantEvents.description: Brokered peace agreements between Egypt and Israel.

significantEvents.title: Iran Hostage Crisis
significantEvents.description: 52 American diplomats and citizens were held hostage in Iran for 444 days.

presidents.name: Ronald Reagan
presidents.burialLocation: Ronald Reagan Presidential Library, Simi Valley, California

significantEvents.title: Reaganomics
significantEvents.description: Economic policies focused on tax cuts, reduced social spending, and deregulation.

significantEvents.title: Iran-Contra Affair
significantEvents.description: A political scandal involving the secret sale of arms to Iran.

presidents.name: George H. W. Bush
presidents.burialLocation: George Bush Presidential Library and Museum, College Station, Texas

significantEvents.title: Gulf War
significantEvents.description: Led a coalition to liberate Kuwait after Iraq's invasion.

significantEvents.title: Americans with Disabilities Act
significantEvents.description: Signed legislation prohibiting discrimination based on disability.

significantEvents.title: North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA)
significantEvents.description: Established a trilateral trade bloc between the U.S., Canada, and Mexico.

significantEvents.title: Impeachment
significantEvents.description: Impeached by the House of Representatives but acquitted by the Senate.

significantEvents.title: September 11 Attacks
significantEvents.description: Terrorist attacks on the U.S., leading to the War on Terror.

significantEvents.title: Iraq War
significantEvents.description: Initiated a military conflict to remove Saddam Hussein from power.

significantEvents.title: Affordable Care Act
significantEvents.description: Health care reform aimed at expanding insurance coverage and reducing costs.

significantEvents.title: Operation Neptune Spear
significantEvents.description: Osama bin Laden was killed in a U.S. Navy SEAL operation in Pakistan.

presidents.name: Donald Trump
presidents.placeOfBirth: Queens, New York City, New York

significantEvents.title: COVID-19 Pandemic
significantEvents.description: Global pandemic that defined much of Trump's last year in office.

significantEvents.title: First Impeachment of Donald Trump
significantEvents.description: The abuse of power charge alleged that Trump used the powers of the presidency to solicit foreign interference in the 2020 election to benefit his reelection campaign, undermining national security and the integrity of U.S. elections.

significantEvents.title: January 6th Capitol Attack
significantEvents.description: A mob of supporters of President Donald Trump attacked the U.S. Capitol in an attempt to overturn the 2020 presidential election results, leading to widespread condemnation and subsequent legal actions.

significantEvents.title: Second Impeachment of Donald Trump
significantEvents.description: Donald Trump became the first U.S. president to be impeached twice when the House of Representatives charged him with incitement of insurrection following the January 6 Capitol attack. He was acquitted in the Senate trial.

significantEvents.title: COVID-19 Response
significantEvents.description: Focused on vaccine distribution and economic recovery efforts.

significantEvents.title: Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act
significantEvents.description: Signed a bipartisan infrastructure bill into law, investing in transportation and utilities.

presidents.name: Donald Trump
presidents.placeOfBirth: Queens, New York City, New York

significantEvents.title: First Week Executive Actions
significantEvents.description: In his first week as 47th president, Trump signed hundreds of executive actions, including withdrawing from the Paris Climate Accords and WHO, reversing Biden-era policies, and pardoning January 6 defendants. The indoor inauguration ceremony was notable for its unconventional nature and the presence of prominent business leaders.
